title: Can Buckethead be considered one of the greatest contemporary guitarist? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Considered” is one of those things that, while obviously subject to concensus, is ultimately subjective. So here’s my take, one which I would wager is roughly shared by many other music fans. Buckethead has composed some great works. His various side-projects with other musicians have often produced at least one great record. However, Buckethead is too prolific for his own good. Now, I won’t pass any judgement as to why he releases so much music, but the net effect on the listener is not only getting overwhelmed, it also leads to getting to the real gems in his vast ouvre. A lot of his stuff is technically impressive, but compositionally not all that. While he doesn’t get as bad as some other shredders (or at least not as often, all things considered), one does get the feeling that if he had someone next to him helping him focus, he could have a considerably more concentrated streak of great albums, rather than putting out dozens a year where only a handful of those feel truly exceptional.

Yeah! as a contemporary guitarist goes, he could be considered among the better players of this generation. To me he’s hit or miss, when hits he’s dead on, when he misses, it isn’t terrible, but he failed to capture that little thing that makes it a good piece of music. No one is going to say that sucked! but they could say “I didn’t get it”, hence the down side of being a musical genius. Sometimes players get lost in the technical part of playing, and lose sight of the music. Think of David Gilmour, and his playing, generally the music got put first, and that sometimes separates great from damned good! Thanks! Robert

Yes he can. He checks all the “boxes”. Theoretically sound. Technical virtuosity. Soulful playing. He can cross multiple genres and is a household name in most guitar circles, even though it may be hard to pinpoint a single “song” of his. In this regard he may be considered THE true contemporary guitarist, given the plethora of genres and subgenres out there these days. It’s almost hard to keep up these days, and it’s always been hard for me to keep up with what Buckethead is up to.

Sure. He’s one of the most technical guitarists in terms of speed and execution - yet his music has so much feeling and emotion, he bred his own instantly recognizable kill-switching technique and sound, and he’s definitely the most prolific guitarist.

I'm not sure I could go that far as there are so many outstanding guitarist out there but he certainly is one of the best around today. Time will tell how he is remembered. Even after forty plus years Hendrix is considered the best ever and there isn't anyone who agrees on who is second.

Yes. Buckethead is a guy who has many, many albums under his belt and has not been sucked in by the fame of it all. In fact, he can easily get up and nip to the shops - the same can not be said for a lot of famous musicians. His technical skill and innovation is very impressive and so is his dedication to avant-garde music.

Technically he’s fantastic and quite a showman. But his volume of work versus his quality lets him down a bit, album after album of ambient guitar works for a whole month really takes away the magic and mystique of his encompassinf talent.
No, but he took lessons from the greatest.
